title: GADD'S HOSTEL
paragraphs: Charles Gadd was the first ranger on Mt. Wellington and he lived in a cottage (the Rangerâ€™s House) at the Springs, where he provided assistance to walkers, oversaw the erection and upgrading of infrastructure, and protected the natural values of the mountain. He also provided overnight shelter to walkers and assisted in rescues, such as during the tragic 1903 Go-As-You-Please race, in which two young men lost their lives.
HERITAGE ASSESSMENTThe building has been assessed as part of The Springs Development Plan and other associated conservation policies, and in Focus on the Fringe.

images.alt: Ranger Gadd's cottage at the Springs. Shelter shed at left. Gadd himself is the figure in this image. Grist collection, J. W. Beattie photo
